papers.abstract: Bone marrow (BM) examination is one of the most important indicators in diagnosing hematologic disorders and is typically performed under the microscope via oil-immersion objective lens with a total 100× objective magnification. On the other hand, mitotic detection and identification is critical not only for accurate cancer diagnosis and grading but also for predicting therapy success and survival. Fully automated BM examination and mitotic figure examination from whole-slide images is highly demanded but challenging and poorly explored. First, the complexity and poor reproducibility of microscopic image examination are due to the cell type diversity, delicate intralineage discrepancy within the multitype cell maturation process, cells overlapping, lipid interference and stain variation. Second, manual annotation on whole-slide images is tedious, laborious and subject to intraobserver variability, which causes the supervised information restricted to limited, easily identifiable and scattered cells annotated by humans. Third, when the training data are sparsely labeled, many unlabeled objects of interest are wrongly defined as background, which severely confuses AI learners. This article presents an efficient and fully automatic CW-Net approach to address the three issues mentioned above and demonstrates its superior performance on both BM examination and mitotic figure examination. The experimental results demonstrate the robustness and generalizability of the proposed CW-Net on a large BM WSI dataset with 16,456 annotated cells of 19 BM cell types and a large-scale WSI dataset for mitotic figure assessment with 262,481 annotated cells of five cell types.

events.Text: Bone marrow (BM) examination is one of the most important indicators in diagnosing hematologic disorders and is typically performed under the microscope via oil-immersion objective lens with a total 100× objective magnification. On the other hand, mitotic detection and identification is critical not only for accurate cancer diagnosis and grading but also for predicting therapy success and survival. Fully automated BM examination and mitotic figure examination from whole-slide images is highly demanded but challenging and poorly explored.
events.Main Action: is highly demanded but challenging and poorly explored.

Agent: 骨髓检查（BM）和细胞学检测

Primary Object: 对血液系统疾病进行诊断的重要性，尤其是对于癌症的诊断和分期
Secondary Object: 预测治疗效果和生存率

Context: Bone marrow (BM) examination is one of the most important indicators in diagnosing hematologic disorders and is typically performed under the microscope via oil-immersion objective lens with a total 100× objective magnification.
On the other hand, mitotic detection and identification is critical not only for accurate cancer diagnosis and grading but also for predicting therapy success and survival.
Challenge: 骨髓检查需要显微镜下的高倍放大观察，而自动化BM检查和细胞形态分析面临技术难题。此外，虽然完全自动化的BM检查和细胞图像分析在理论上可行，但在实际操作中由于低通量而导致其应用受限。
Implications: 如果不能实现完全自动化的BM检查和细胞图像分析，则可能会影响临床诊断效率和准确性，进而影响患者预后评估和治疗方案制定。因此，探索更高效的自动化方法以平衡图像质量与检出能力之间的关系具有重要意义。
Contradictions: 骨髓检查的传统方式依赖于显微镜下油浸 objectives下的高倍放大学生视野，并且只能完成简单的计数任务；然而，完全自动化的BM检查和细胞图像分析不仅能够提高检出速度和精度，还能为癌细胞的诊断提供更多的辅助信息。

events.Text: First, the complexity and poor reproducibility of microscopic image examination are due to the cell type diversity, delicate intralineage discrepancy within the multitype cell maturation process, cells overlapping, lipid interference and stain variation. Second, manual annotation on whole-slide images is tedious, laborious and subject to intraobserver variability, which causes the supervised information restricted to limited, easily identifiable and scattered cells annotated by humans. Third, when the training data are sparsely labeled, many unlabeled objects of interest are wrongly defined as background, which severely confuses AI learners. This article presents an efficient and fully automatic CW-Net approach to address the three issues mentioned above and demonstrates its superior performance on both BM examination and mitotic figure examination.

Primary Object: an efficient and fully automatic CW-Net approach
Secondary Object: to address the three issues mentioned above and demonstrate its superior performance on both BM examination and mitotic figure examination

Method: an efficient and fully automatic CW-Net approach
Results: demonstrates its superior performance on both BM examination and mitotic figure examination
Implications: This suggests the method enhances automated microscopy workflows, improving diagnostic capabilities and reducing human effort required for evaluations.

events.Text: The experimental results demonstrate the robustness and generalizability of the proposed CW-Net on a large BM WSI dataset with 16,456 annotated cells of 19 BM cell types and a large-scale WSI dataset for mitotic figure assessment with 262,481 annotated cells of five cell types.

Primary Object: robustness and generalizability of the proposed CW-Net

Results: The experimental results demonstrate the robustness and generalizability of the proposed CW-Net on a large BM WSI dataset with 16,456 annotated cells of 19 BM cell types and a large-scale WSI dataset for mitotic figure assessment with 262,481 annotated cells of five cell types.

papers.abstract: ManyFold is a flexible library for protein structure prediction with deep learning that (i) supports models that use both multiple sequence alignments (MSAs) and protein language model (pLM) embedding as inputs, (ii) allows inference of existing models (AlphaFold and OpenFold), (iii) is fully trainable, allowing for both fine-tuning and the training of new models from scratch and (iv) is written in Jax to support efficient batched operation in distributed settings. A proof-of-concept pLM-based model, pLMFold, is trained from scratch to obtain reasonable results with reduced computational overheads in comparison to AlphaFold.

events.Text: ManyFold is a flexible library for protein structure prediction with deep learning that (i) supports models that use both multiple sequence alignments (MSAs) and protein language model (pLM) embedding as inputs, (ii) allows inference of existing models (AlphaFold and OpenFold), (iii) is fully trainable, allowing for both fine-tuning and the training of new models from scratch and (iv) is written in Jax to support efficient batched operation in distributed settings.
A proof-of-concept pLM-based model, pLMFold, is trained from scratch to obtain reasonable results with reduced computational overheads in comparison to AlphaFold.

Secondary Object: reduced computational overheads in comparison to AlphaFold

Context: A proof-of-concept pLM-based model, pLMFold, is trained from scratch to obtain reasonable results with reduced computational overheads in comparison to AlphaFold.
Results: Obtaining reasonable results with reduced computational overheads in comparison to AlphaFold.
